newsitem.title: USA: TransTexas sees Q4 net below consensus.
newsitem.headline: TransTexas sees Q4 net below consensus.

text.p: TransTexas Gas Corp said it expects increased production and improved natural gas prices to generate fourth quarter earnings per share of $0.37, below the $0.40 consensus being reported by First Call for the three months ending January 31.
The company said its cash flow for the current quarter will be about $0.90 per share; and earnings before interest, taxes, depletion, depreciation and amortization are expected to exceed $90 million.
For the year earlier quarter, TransTexas noted, it reported a loss of $0.17 and EBITDA of $47.4 million.
The difference between the company's expectations for fourth quarter earnings and the consensus of analyst estimates is tax treatment, TransTexas spokesman Simon Ward said.

Stating it was responding to analyst inquiries concerning the impact of commodity pricing, the company said it realized an average natural gas sales prices of slightly over $3.00 per thousand cubic feet in the first two months of the quarter.

Currently, TransTexas said, it is receiving over $3.40 per thousand cubic feet for deliveries at its Agua Dulce, Texas, marketing hub and it expects that the average for January will exceed $3.25 per thousand cubic feet.

Additionally, pricing of natural gas liquids that TransTexas Transmission Corp extracts from its gas production stream have increased to more than $0.40 per gallon and are further improving margins, the company said.

It noted that production of natural gas and oil have improved largely as a result of its development of the Bob West North and Fandango South natural gas fields in Texas and the new Lodgepole oil field discovery in North Dakota.

TransTexas said it is now the third largest producer of natural gas in Texas with gross natural gas and oil production capacity, including third-party operated wells, of 800 million cubic feet equivalent per day.
About 300 million of this is coming from the Lobo Trend, Ward said.
He declined to comment on a published report the company is close to an agreement to sell its Lobo Trend field to DuPont Co's Conoco Inc subsidiary.
A Conoco spokesman also declined to comment on the report.

Ward did say the company has "had several interested parties come into (its) data room" since announcing in late August it had engaged investment bankers to help with the sale of its Lobo properties in Webb and Zapata counties of South Texas.

Included, it said at the time, is a 1,100 mile pipeline system from the Lobo Trend to the Agua Dulce marketing hub near Corpus Christi, Texas, and the company's interest in North Dakota's Lodgepole formation.
